960912060912726016.text: One more time, Clayton says there are “pure cryptocurrencies and then there are securities offerings.” Two separate things.

960902346418028544.text: Right now there’s a room in DC full of senators and top regulators talking about the technology you’ve dedicated your life to.http://coincenter.org/donate

960896219353702400.text: Chairman Giancarlo: “We owe it to this new generation to respect their interest in this new technology with a thoughtful regulatory approach.”

960897166549159936.text: Senators and top regulators smile when talking about how they've discussed Bitcoin at the dinner table with their kids.

960895939899723776.text: Chairman Clayton: Every ICO I've seen is a security, we have jurisdiction, we will enforce, laws have private right of actions, and we will work with DOJ.

960894088663982081.text: The chairman and ranking member’s statements have both acknowledged the positive aspects of Bitcoin and took for granted that Americans have a right to own and employ it.

960896522111119360.text:
Chairman Clayton: Neither the SEC or the CFTC have jursidcition over spot markets for "true cryptocurrencies." 
"Please do not interpret this as us asking for increased SEC jurisdiction."

960860732756807680.text: A number of people were confused by one of my takeaways from Clayton's testimony. I think it stems from not understanding the nature of securities law (which is far less deterministic than you might expect). Thread:https://twitter.com/valkenburgh/status/960859774916157440 …

CFTC: https://twitter.com/jerrybrito/status/960577079975776257 …

SEC:https://twitter.com/valkenburgh/status/960572899886288897 …

960577079975776257.text: Happy to see that Chairman @giancarloCFTC is highlighting the inefficiency of state-by-state regulation of cryptocurrency exchanges. If Congress picks this up, policy should include federal preemption AND safe harbor for non-custodial users. 1/2pic.twitter.com/H4SjN7eOoM

960574746797772805.text: 12/ All in all, very comprehensive, helpful, and encouraging portrait of the cryptocurrency regulatory space. Confident "we got this" from the Chairman.

960574478492360706.text: 11/ ON LEVERAGE: "I am particularly concerned about market participants who extend to customers credit in U.S. dollars – a relatively stable asset – to enable the purchase of cryptocurrencies, which, in recent experience, have proven to be a more volatile asset."

960574308262309889.text: 10/ ON REG D: "It is possible to conduct an offer and sales of securities, including an ICO, without triggering the SEC’s registration requirements. just as with a Regulation D exempt offering [for products], an ICO that is a security can be structured so that it qualifies."

960573917499985921.text: 9/ Coin Center has a brand new report on exactly how Congress and Federal regulators could go about rationalizing the state-by-state approach:https://coincenter.org/entry/money-transmission-licensing-is-broken-here-s-how-to-fix-it …

960573594978979840.text: 8/ ON STATES AND UNIFIED FEDERAL APPROACH: "we are open to exploring with Congress, as well as with our federal and state colleagues, whether increased federal regulation of cryptocurrency trading platforms is necessary or appropriate.

960573503136325632.text: 7/ ON STATES: "U.S.-based cryptocurrency trading platforms have elected to be regulated as money-transmission services. ... these predominantly state-regulated payment services have not been subject to direct oversight by the SEC or the CFTC."

960573289180618753.text: 6/ ...ambit of a securities offer and sale is a facts-and-circumstances analysis, utilizing a principles-based framework that has served American companies and American investors well through periods of innovation and change for over 80 years." e.g. old tools = best tools.

960573133978824705.text: 5/ ON HOWEY TEST & CLASSIFICATION OF CRYPTO: "there are cryptocurrencies that, at least as currently designed, promoted and used, do not appear to be securities" Very clear and significant; didn't say which but that'd be a lot to ask. Also: "determining what falls within the...

960573064412090369.text: 4/ ON INNOVATION: "These warnings are not an effort to undermine the fostering of innovation through our capital markets – America was built on the ingenuity, vision and spirit of entrepreneurs who tackled old and new problems in new, innovative ways."

960573010808852480.text: 3/ Additionally, interesting tidbits: (a) Reg D works for ICOs e.g. SAFT sales can fit (b) concern over leveraged trading (c) ETF will take time to sort out issues, not ready now.

960572946786988037.text: 2/ Clayton emphasizes (1) preserving innovation (2) continued efficacy of Howey test for judging whether crypto/token is a security (3) SEC & CFTC together have situation under control (4) states may not be the best choice for preeminent regulator of exchanges.

1050411002771267585.text: Here is @valkenburgh's testimony: The public internet needs public payments infrastructurehttps://coincenter.org/entry/the-public-internet-needs-public-payments-infrastructure …

1050405128325554177.text: If you watched today's cryptocurrency hearing and like what you saw, consider donating to help us continue our work.https://coincenter.org/donate

1050395444331855872.text: Thanks to the support of our donors big and small, Coin Center is able to testify today and put a strong foot forward for cryptocurrency.http://www.coincenter.org/donate

1050390702398590976.text: "The technology is not yet ready to answer all of those questions today but it is our best hope, and as with the Internet in the 90s, we need light-touch pro-innovation policy to ensure that these innovations flourish in America for the benefit and security of all Americans"

1050390701526188033.text: "Blockchains could similarly disintermediate critical payments and IOT infrastructure."

1050390700540485633.text: "The Internet removed single points of failure in communications infrastructure and ushered in a wave of competition among new media corporations building on top of its public rails."

1050390699445837826.text: " It doesn’t matter if the point of failure is a corporation or the government, there shouldn’t be a single point of failure." - @valkenburgh

1050390698451771394.text: "Why should we want to build more public infrastructure? Why should we embrace blockchains over corporations? Why should we tolerate their inefficiencies and work to make them better. Why should we want the pioneers of this technology to be here, in the US and not flee overseas."

1050390697386418176.text: "And it’s just the beginning. If we can replace private payments infrastructure, we can replace other private chokepoints to human interaction as well." - @valkenburgh

1050390696392306689.text: "Bitcoin’s not the best money on every margin. . . . But it is working, and the mere fact that it works without trusted intermediaries is amazing; a breakthrough in computer science and as significance for freedom, prosperity, and human flourishing as the birth of the Internet."

1050390695423500288.text: "Bitcoin is the world’s first globally-accessible online money." - @valkenburgh

1050390694437769216.text: "Anyone, regardless of their nationality, race, religion, sex, or credit-worthiness can (for absolutely no cost) create a bitcoin address in order to receive payments digitally." - @valkenburgh

1050390693351485441.text: "Before Bitcoin, if you wanted to pay someone remotely—over the phone, wire, or internet—then you could not use public infrastructure. You would rely on a private bank to open their books and add a ledger entry that debits you and credits the person you are paying."- @valkenburgh

1050390692088991749.text: "We have public information infrastructure for websites and email, it’s called the Internet, but the only public payments infrastructure that we have is cash, as in paper money, and it only works for face to face transactions." - @valkenburgh

1050390691053035521.text: "The lack of any corporation in between means that bitcoin is the world’s first public digital payments infrastructure. And by public I simply mean open to all and not owned by any single entity." - @valkenburgh

1050390689824026624.text: "Why is it revolutionary? Because unlike every other tool for sending value over the internet, it works without the need to trust a middle-man." - @valkenburgh

1050390688758726656.text: "What does Bitcoin do? It’s easy. It lets you send and receive value to and from anyone in the world using nothing more than a computer with an internet connection." - @valkenburgh

1050390687789801472.text: "What is Bitcoin? Bitcoin is the world's first cryptocurrency and it works because of the world’s first public blockchain network." - @valkenburgh
